subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Unicode Status
msgSnippet: ... That’s not fair. ... That’s true now, but I’m considering to submit a Shavian keyboard layout to Freedesktop. It would be based on the US Qwerty
messageBody:
Le 16/04/13 17:54, Michael Everson a écrit :
> On 16 Apr 2013, at 15:48, Jean-François Colson<jf@...> wrote:
>
>>> It's the one that's going to get results. Don't worry. You will be able to use the fonts you prefer, and you won't have to worry about how things are encoded.
>> No. In an internet café, I won’t be able to install a Quikscript font if only a Shavian font is available on the computer.
> True. So in some contexts you may have to make do with reading Shavian letters.
That’s not fair.

> But you'd not be able to type either Quikscript or Shavian on an internet cafe because you wouldn't be able to install a keyboard.
That’s true now, but I’m considering to submit a Shavian keyboard layout
to Freedesktop. It would be based on the US Qwerty layout and the
traditional 8-bit Shavian fonts. So in a few months GNU/Linux could
begin to have a keyboard layout available by default.

Since most internet cafés use M$ Windows…
I’m used to the bépo keyboard layout for the Latin alphabet (
http://bepo.fr/wiki/Accueil ). For Windows, there are several drivers,
including one you can use without any administrator rights:
http://bepo.fr/wiki/Portable_Keyboard_Layout
I have used it on several very protected systems. As long as there’s a
USB plug or an internet access, I’ve always been able to use it.
Presently, PKL only works with BMP characters, but since it is a free
software, it would be possible to modify it or to compile a completely
new program using Autohotkey. So, I wouldn’t be able to install a
Shavian/QS keyboard now, but things could have changed in a few years,
when QS would be added to Unicode.




>> In a plain text document, I won’t be able to mix Shavian and Quikscript text.
> You will, orthographically. But I can't say that I believe that there is any chance whatsoever that the UCS will have both Shavian and Quikscript as two separate scripts.
Why?

>> To mix Shavian and Quikscript text in the same document, I’ll need to endlessly change the font every time I change the script, while I may mix a Latin z, a Greek ζ and a cyrillic з using a single font and one of my multiscript home-made keyboard layouts if I wish.
> Yes, that's right. But Quikscript isn't a separate script. It's a cursive variety of Shavian with some extensions. I'm sorry if this strikes you as unfortunate, but in the first place *I'm* not convinced, and even if I were, I can't think of any way that I could make a credible case to the UTC and WG2 about it.

Couldn’t you try it?
If it was accepted, that would be wonderful!
If it was rejected, it would still be possible to propose a few
extensions to the Shavian alphabet.

JF
